page.content: never needed. The heyday of the works may well be beyond living memory, but not without testimony from the past. In the 1780's the Horsehay Works was owned by Abraham Darby 111. It was the most important of the Darby works. The evidence from this time is to be found in the houses around the works and in the furnace pool. Looking on to the furnace pool is the Old Row Cottages, Nos 3 to 17, a long row of 15 brick cottages, two storeys high,and two windows per cottage with wooden casements. The first floor windows are under small gables. The houses were built in the 1750's to house the workers in the ironworks. At that time each cottage consisted of four rooms. Though the modern owners have extended them at the back, and added gabled kitchens etc.
